Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Inflammation as a Key Component of the Metabolic Adaptations to the Lactating State
Award.AbstractNarration:
The immune system is responsible for defending the body against pathogens and mediating the responses to some injuries through inflammatory processes. Inflammation can also impact metabolism and energy use. This award will support studies to test whether the non-defensive roles of the immune system are necessary for the metabolic transitions that occur with the onset of lactation, a period when energy use in an animal undergoes extreme changes. The question will be assessed through the use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug administration at the start of lactation in cattle because they are well suited for these studies and are very tractable experimental systems. This project will support research training for under-represented students at the nexus of biology, agriculture, and medicine, provide unique experience for several advanced trainees, and generate transformative information relevant to a broad spectrum of the public. Under-represented students will be recruited to participate in the entire research process, from treatment application to presentation of results. A post-doctoral associate and PhD students will also be mentored. Additional societal benefit may be afforded by utilization of the basic research results for the development of applied management strategies in agriculture.

The objective of this research is to assess whether endogenous inflammation in early lactation is necessary to induce insulin resistance and conserve glucose as nutrient demands for the mammary gland increase. Basal and insulin-stimulated glucose kinetics, as well as liver, muscle, and adipose tissue markers of inflammation and insulin signaling will be measured in cows at high and low milking frequency. Milking frequency will alter milk yield, allowing for the assessment of whether inflammation-mediated homeorhetic processes are particularly important for supporting extreme milk yields. By blocking endogenous low-grade inflammation in early lactation, anti-inflammatory treatment is expected to increase insulin sensitivity, resulting in increased muscle and adipose tissue utilization of glucose, suppressed liver gluconeogenesis, and impaired regulation of plasma glucose concentration in early lactation. Results from the studies will be disseminated through peer-reviewed journals and through presentations at scientific meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The onset of lactation places many new demands on a mother, including the metabolic demands for milk synthesis. The high nutrient requirements of lactation are even more challenging to meet initially because of the illness behavior associated with the birthing process. It remains unclear exactly how maternal physiology adapts to meet these challenges.

Mild inflammation appears to be a common condition in the days after birthing, across species. Dairy cattle, selected for high milk yield and accustomed to human handling, were used as a model to better understand how inflammation in early lactation may play an adaptive role in meeting the metabolic demands of milk production.

Prior research had revealed a decline in blood glucose concentration in response to anti-inflammatory drug treatment of early lactation cows, but it was unclear whether this was due to a drop in production of glucose by the liver or an increase in the use rate of glucose. In this work, we measured liver production and whole-body use of glucose, as well as signaling in liver, muscle, and adipose tissue of early lactation dairy cows.

Somewhat surprisingly, our findings demonstrated that anti-inflammatory treatment (sodium salicylate) did not enhance use of glucose by muscle and adipose tissue as we hypothesized. Instead, anti-inflammatory treatment decreased liver glucose production. Furthermore, this suppression of glucose production appeared to occur even when blood insulin concentrations were very low, suggesting that it did not primarily work by enhancing insulin responsiveness of the liver. These findings strongly suggest that inflammatory mechanisms play an important beneficial role in accelerating liver glucose production to support the onset of lactation. Although similar mechanisms have been uncovered in diabetic models, this is the first such finding in a low-insulin context.

Our work provides an important physiological vantage point from which to consider metabolic inflammation. In most research on the topic, its pathological aspects are highlighted (e.g., metabolic syndrome), with little consideration of why these apparently harmful effects are conserved across species. Metabolic inflammation may be critical to adaptation during major physiological challenges or transitions, including the start of lactation. Over the life of the project, these findings and concepts were shared with both scientific and agricultural audiences through 7 presentations at conferences in North America and Europe. 

In addition to scientific information, this project provided an opportunity for unique technical and communication training for 3 undergraduate students, a graduate student, and a post-doctoral scholar (all women). These trainees each had the opportunity to present findings at symposia or conferences, and two won awards for their efforts.

In summary, the project provided new information relevant to management of dairy cows after giving birth, and it has been widely communicated to dairy managers and consultants. More broadly, our newfound understanding of inflammation’s impacts on liver glucose production will influence management of metabolic health across species. Finally, five trainees learned unique methods and gained a wide variety of professional skills in conducting this research.
